name: Dashi

ingredients.name: kombu dried kelp
ingredients.original_string: 3/4 ounce/21 grams kombu (dried kelp), or the equivalent of 3 (4-inch-square) pieces

ingredients.name: very tightly packed cups 28 grams shaved katsuobushi also called hana-katsuo; smoked
ingredients.original_string: 3 very tightly packed cups/28 grams shaved katsuobushi (also called hana-katsuo; smoked and dried bonito flakes)

instructions: Combine the kombu with the cold water in a donabe or Dutch oven and let soak for at least 20 minutes. (If time permits, soaking for 2 to 3 hours or up to overnight is even better. In this case, use a separate bowl for soaking, then transfer the contents to the donabe when they are ready.) When the kombu is soft, cut some slits in it with scissors so the kombu will release more flavor.
Set the donabe over medium-low heat and slowly bring the liquid with the kombu to a low simmer, about 30 minutes. Remove the kombu (see Tip).

Increase the heat to medium and bring the liquid to a high simmer, about 5 minutes, then immediately turn off the heat. Add the katsuobushi all at once, then let it settle under the surface of the liquid, about 2 minutes. Gently strain the dashi through a fine-mesh sieve into a large bowl. (Resist the temptation to press the katsuobushi to extract more flavor, or youâ€™ll end up with a dashi that tastes more overtly fishy than oceanic.) Dashi keeps, refrigerated, for a few days.
